subject: Origin Energy (ORG AT) says FY20 capex is estimated to be 5%-10% lower than guidance of USD 530mln-580mln
RBNZ purchases NZD 585mln of 2025-2031 government vovs. target of NZD 600mln
RBA adds AUD 770mln to banking system through repos vs. Prev. AUD 197mln
PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: Japan will declare a State of Emergency as early as Tuesday
content:
AUSTRALIA

ASX (ASX AT) - Co. March average daily number of trades rose 96% Y/Y to 3.06mln. (Newswires)

Caltex (CTX AT) - Co. will bring forward and extends planned shutdown of Lytton refinery which will now commence on May 2020, while its target 2020 group capex will be lowered to under USD 250mln from prior target of USD 300mln. (Newswires)

Dexus (DXS AT) - Co. is expected to partner with GIC to acquire 50% stake of Rialto Towers in Melbourne for AUD 644mln. (AFR)

Flight Centre (FLT AT) - Co. announces AUD 700mln share placement. (Newswires)

Lend Lease (LLC AT) - Co. is said to be gauging market interest for AUD 1.0bln capital raise. (Newswires)

Magellan Financial Group (MFG AT) - Co. March FUM AUD 93.9bln vs. Prev. AUD 100.7bln. (Newswires)

National Storage REIT (NSR AT) - Abacus Property Group (ABP AT) is speculated to have raised its stake in the Co. to around 4.2% over the past weeks. (Newswires)

Oil Search (OSH AT) - Co. shares halted amid capital raising announcement. (Newswires)

Reliance Worldwide (RWC AT) - Co. is to furlough 40% of its UK workforce. (Newswires)

Seek (SEK AT) - Co. will defer FY20 interim dividend to July. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Asahi Co. (3333 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 2.6bln vs. Prev. JPY 2.4bln Y/Y, increases FY annual dividend plan to JPY 18/Shr from JPY 16/Shr. (Newswires)

Unizo Holdings (3258 JT) - Co. notes takeover bid from Lone Star was successful. (Newswires)

Ratings - S&P affirmed Japan at A+; Outlook Positive. (Newswires)

Other News - Japan will declare a State of Emergency as early as Tuesday. (Yomiuri)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Celltrion (068270 KS) - Co. announced the coronavirus antiviral treatment enters the next phase of development. (Newswires)

Hyundai Motor (005380 KS) - Co. is reportedly extending warranties for more than 1mln vehicles globally. (Newswires)

Paradise (034230 KS) - Co. extends casino shutdown to April 13th. (Newswires)

Ssangyong (003620 KS) - Mahindra and Mahindra (MM IS) board took decision not to inject fresh equity into the Co. (Newswires)

subject: US VP Pence says spoke to a number of state governors on Sunday and all of those states are seeing a trend of some levelling in coronavirus cases
RBA says excess cash at exchange settlement accounts at AUD 81.7bln vs. Prev. 78.2bln

US President Trump says have bought a tremendous amount of hydroxychloroquine and suggests some very strong signs it helps combat coronavirus infections, adds use of erythromycin to treat coronavirus should be looked at very closely
content:
Says:

  • US is very far down the line on developing vaccines for coronavirus and we'll see what happens.
  • We're starting to see light at the end of the tunnel.

subject: US President Trump says we hope we're seeing a levelling off for coronavirus in the hottest spots
US President Trump says drop in number of New York deaths could be a good sign
UK GfK Consumer Confidence (Mar) -34 (Prev. -9); weakest reading since Feb. 2009
ASIAN DAILY ECONOMIC RELEASE CALENDAR IS NOW AVAILABLE IN THE RESEARCH SECTION: Highlights include: Australian MI Inflation Gauge and India Services PMI; China and India are closed for holidays
Mexico President AMLO says will announce USD 13.5bln program of public investment in the energy industry next week
RBNZ offers to buy Local Government Funding Agency bonds on a small scale for liquidity management
Japan reportedly will declare a state of emergency as early as Tuesday, according to Japanese press

US equity futures begin the week on the front-foot with Emini S&P higher by 1.4% and back above the 2500 level, while oil prices suffer with WTI crude down about 9% after the OPEC+ meeting was pushed back to Thursday as Saudi and Russia tensions flare
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE / RESPONSES

WHO said it is possible some element of airborne transmission could be seen in the spread of the coronavirus although the main driver is still symptomatic people coughing, sneezing or contaminating others and surfaces. (Newswires)

US President Trump commented there is going to be a lot of deaths in the next 2 weeks related to coronavirus and stated that CDC is advising wearing face coverings on a voluntary basis, while the White House confirmed US President Trump signed DPA order aimed at preventing hoarding and exports of personal protective equipment. (Newswires)

US President Trump's administration is reportedly expected to use the coronavirus relief funds to pay hospitals that treat uninsured patients as long as they are not billed. (WSJ)

Italy’s coronavirus death toll rose by 525 to 15,887 which was its smallest daily increase since March 19th and the number of confirmed cases rose by 4316 to 128,948 which is the slowest pace of increase in 5 days. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson was taken to hospital for tests due to the coronavirus which Downing Street stated was a precautionary step as the PM has persistent symptoms 10 days after having tested positive. (Newswires)

Spanish PM Sanchez extended the coronavirus state of emergency until April 26th. (Newswires)

German Chancellor Merkel said it is too early to know when lockdowns will be eased and will depend on virus progress. In related news, German Finance Minister Scholz plans a EUR 50bln post-virus economic stimulus package and plans to use reserves that were intended for dealing with refugees, while it was also reported that Germany are considering a EUR 300bln guarantee programme for small companies. (Newswires/Spiegel)

Australian scientists found that Ivermectin which is produced by Merck for treatment of parasites and head lice was successful in killing coronavirus within 48 hours and next phase will be for human trials, although Australian health authorities warned the public against attempting to treat coronavirus at home which could be fatal. (Newswires/Metro)

 

ASIA-PAC

PBoC lowered RRR for some banks by 100bps which could release around CNY 400bln in funds and will be implemented in two phases with a 50bps reduction on April 15th and a similar cut on May 15th, while the PBoC are to lower interest on excess reserves for financial institutions to 0.35% from 0.72% effective April 7th. (Newswires)

China is likely to issue CNY 3 to 4 trln (USD 423bln to 565bln) in special treasury bonds in 2020 to give the coronavirus-hit economy a much-needed shot in the arm. (Global Times)

 

UK/EU

S&P affirmed France at AA; Outlook Stable and Germany at AAA; Outlook Stable, while Fitch affirmed Belgium at AA-; Outlook revised to Negative. (Newswires)

EU Retail Sales (Feb) Y/Y 3.0% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%, Rev. 2.2%). (Newswires)

 

FX

Bank of Canada announced the activation of its Contingent Term Repo Facility (CTRF) from 6th April and will remain open for 12 months. (Newswires) 

 

COMMODITIES

OPEC+ meeting has been delayed a few days and will now be conducted on Thursday instead of the initially planned Monday. (Newswires)

US President Trump said we will work this out and get our energy business back, while he added the Saudi Crown Prince and Russia’s President want something to happen. However, he commented over the weekend that he couldn’t care less about OPEC and they are destroying themselves, while he added they will impose tariffs on crude imports if needed to protect US energy workers from the oil price crash. (Newswires)

NEC Director Kudlow said US President Trump told Russia and Saudi to stop "colluding" and oversupplying the oil market, while he added the US can make sure there is a level playing field in the oil and he believes that Saudi and Russia have ended their disagreement in the oil market. (Newswires)

US President Trump administration discussed shutting oil production in the Gulf of Mexico due to COVID-19 spread across offshore platforms, which would cut around 2mln BPD from the total 13mln BPD of US production, according to sources.(WSJ)

Saudi Arabia denied comments from Russian President Putin that claimed Saudi withdrew from the OPEC+ agreement and instead blamed Russia for abandoning the deal. (Newswires)

Russian President Putin said the situation on the global energy markets remains difficult and demand is falling, while he is comfortable with oil at USD 42/bbl. Russian President Putin spoke to US President Trump saying "we are all worried about the situation" and are ready to act with the US on oil markets, while he added that Russia wants joint actions on oil markets and that cuts should be made from the Q1 levels. Furthermore, he alleged that Saudi plans to get rid of shale oil producers and suggested the reason for oil price collapse is the coronavirus, lack of oil demand and Saudi Arabia withdrawal from the OPEC+ deal. (Newswires)

Russia Energy Minister Novak spoke with President Putin in which he told him we do not know when oil demand will reach its lows and that it is unfortunate Saudi Arabia announced plans to increase production. Novak added that Saudi is still negatively influencing oil market and that it is necessary for oil production cuts from everybody, including US and Saudi Arabia in which a cut should be for the next few months and gradually recovered thereafter. (Newswires)

Russian producers are reportedly ready for oil cuts in order to stop the price rout, in which the industry may agree to cuts if the US and Saudi joins. (Newswires)

Under OPEC+ scenarios 10mln BPD cuts will include North America and Saudi Arabia would cut a minimum of 3mln BPD, Russia 1.5mln BPD while US, Canada and Brazil would cut almost 2mln BPD (Texas at least 500k BPD), according to sources. (WSJ)

US Energy Secretary Brouillette commented they are still planning on purchasing oil despite the opposition, while there were also comments from President Trump that the Energy Secretary should look at other areas to store oil. (Newswires)

Texas Railroad Commissioner Sitton said he doesn't see the US having a long relationship with OPEC at all and that Texas would agree to oil production curbs if President Trump reaches an international agreement. (Newswires)

IEA said OPEC+ 10mln BPD cut is not sufficient to balance the market. (Newswires)

Baker Hughes US Rig Count (w/e April 3rd): Oil -62 at 562, Nat Gas -2 at 100, Total -64 at 664. (Newswires)

 

US

Wisconsin State is to conduct in person voting on Tuesday after the state legislature declined to delay the vote despite the coronavirus outbreak. (Newswires)

  • US Non-Farm Payrolls (Mar) -701k vs. Exp. -100.0k (Prev. 273.0k, Rev. 275k); 1st contraction since September 2010. (Newswires)
  • US Unemployment Rate (Mar) 4.4% vs. Exp. 3.8% (Prev. 3.5%)
  • US Average Earnings YY (Mar) 3.1% vs. Exp. 3.0% (Prev. 3.0%)
  • US ISM Non-Manufacturing PMI (Mar) 52.5 vs. Exp. 44.0 (Prev. 57.3)
  • US Markit Services PMI Final (Mar) 39.8 (Prev. 39.1)
  • US Markit Composite Final PMI (Mar) 40.9 (Prev. 40.5)

 

MARKET RECAP

Stocks drifted lower through the session to end the week as the TPLEX bull-flattened, failing to benefit from another strong day for crude oil prices, as pessimism on the economic outlook overshadows any optimism, the fact the market didn’t knee-jerk react to a -700k print in NFP highlights the bearish sentiment. The crude benchmarks had another session of double-digit percentage gains, seeing WTI move above 28/bbl and Brent above 34/bbl, as OPEC+ plus North America look set to hold a conference call on Monday with discussion over a 10mln BPD cut, although concerns linger on how committed the US will be to such proposals. Apple (AAPL) lower after Credit Suisse cuts PT, citing prolonged COVID-19 closures and lockdowns weighing on demand (MS also cut its PT); it will also be keeping US retail stores closed until May. Disney (DIS) was lower after announcing it will furlough workers. Tesla (TSLA) surged after revealing better than expected Q1 deliveries. 3M (MMM) came under pressure amid a hostile tweet from US President Trump who stated the co. “will have a big price to pay” after being hit hard by the Trump administration to see what it is doing with its masks. Boeing (BA) announced it is to temporarily suspend operations at its Philadelphia, Ridley Township facilities for two weeks. American Airlines (AAL) is to further reduce flights with April flights being cut between 70-75% and around 80% in May as demand plummets amid the coronavirus. SPX -1.51% at 2489, NDX -1.41% at 7528, DJIA -1.69% at 21052.5.

The TPLEX bull flattened, catching upward momentum in the US session as equities drifted lower and a cooling in corporate issuance – the -700k NFP report had little immediate market impact. One desk noted that the bid was mostly a function of leveraged fund types, although real money did “nibble”. Furthermore, corporate issuance took a breather on Friday, with just a couple of IG issuers, likely supporting the bid out the curve. FedEx (FDX) was one of the issuers, raising capital further out the curve in order to pay off credit facilities it had drawn down on. This method has become more frequent recently, and is supporting the bounce back in issuance, as corporates raise capital in longer maturities to address their large credit facility drawdowns and commercial paper issuance. Meanwhile, the Fed continued its Treasury purchases (at the reduced clip of USD 60bln per day), also supporting the flattener, and in contrast to recent sessions, Treasuries maintained their bid after the Fed completed its purchases, whereas recent sessions have seen participants selling into the operations. By settlement, 2s -1bps at 0.21%, 10s -4bps at 0.59%, 30s -5bps at 1.22%. T-NOTE (M0) FUTURES SETTLED 8 TICKS HIGHER AT 139-04+.

subject: ANALYSIS: OPEC+ call delayed until Thursday
content:
• OPEC: An OPEC+ call that was scheduled for Monday has been delayed until Thursday, amid an intensifying dispute between Russia and Saudi Arabia over who is to blame for falling crude prices. Participants are to discuss the demand hit to crude from COVID-19. Analysts do not seem to be convinced that the group will make sufficient progress; the Saudis and Russia have called for other global producers – namely US, Canada and Mexico – to share the burden of cuts, while Norway has also said it would consider cutting production in any coordinated global effort.
  • LEVEL OF CUTS: Ahead of the now notorious March OPEC meeting, there was a recommendation to cut an additional 1.5mln BPD from April 2020 through the end of 2020, with a review in June. The deal was conditional on support from OPEC+, and OPEC said any deal could only be applied on a pro-rata basis, and proposed core members cut by 1mln BPD, and non-OPEC by 500k. Ahead of Thursday's meeting, a figure of 10mln BPD cut to output has been floated (around 10% of global supply), although following a call with Saudi Arabia, US President Trump last week indicated that it could be as much as 15mln BPD. A source has suggested that the 10mln should be slashed from current levels of output. Either way, Goldman Sachs thinks that the demand hit might actually be more like 26mln BPD, and a cut of 10mln BPD may prove to be insufficient.
  • TEXAS: The Trump administration has previously signalled it would not impose mandatory curbs on companies' production, given the antitrust legislation, although Stratfor's analysts note that Texas, where field production was running at a pace of 5.37mln BPD at the end of 2019, does have the legal framework to be able do so at a state level. One of the three Texas Railroad Commission members, Ryan Sitton, has indicated a willingness to agree production cuts to support oil prices and prevent producers in the state going bust. Texas regulators are to meet on 14th April to discuss production curbs in the state, and may vote on any resolution a week later, Reuters reported. Sitton, however, is a lame duck on the Commission, having lost in the March primary to a challenger, and his term concludes in December; the state's two other regulators, Wayne Christian and Christi Craddick, have not publicly endorsed cuts. Meanwhile, US President Trump on the weekend said he was considering slapping tariffs on oil imports, or even take other such measures, in order to protect the US energy sector from falling oil prices; Canada is reportedly also mulling such steps. This follows calls by leading lawmakers in recent weeks for such action. For reference, the US imports of petroleum were around 9.1mln BPD in 2019, of which Saudi and Russian imports were just over 500k each.
  • WHAT TO WATCH: Talk of further production cuts was supportive for crude prices last week, and were participants not able to strike a deal, oil could again find itself under pressure. In terms the signposts to watch, Stratfor suggests monitoring Saudi willingness to go back to letting Russia cut a much smaller amount, or an openness to a Texas-only US commitment. "In any case, a deal keeping Brent above USD 30/bbl does not seem the most likely outcome," it said. Additionally, others have noted that Saudi Arabia delayed publishing its official selling prices for May until 10th April (a day after the call), an unprecedented measure to allow stakeholders more time to reach a deal ahead of Thursday's call, a source said; the data was due to be published on Sunday, and it will this week be useful in corroborating how the meeting really went.
